discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] What is the upper limit on how many CUs delegates can effectively oversee?

content.content: Historically, CU onboarding has been evaluated strictly on the merit of the CU, but there is a hidden cost. Every added CU takes time and energy that could be spent on other CUs or projects within the protocol. With the recent discussion of increased oversight and potential KPIs for CUs, I thought we should get a rough idea of what upper limit we should aim for. Conventional wisdom is that a manager can handle 7-10 direct reports. Someone overseeing multiple departments would generally handle 3-5. While Maker delegates are not managers, I do think the 7-10 number is a good rough heuristic. It would be helpful to know how the general community feels about the subject. Note: This is independent of budget considerations. This is strictly an organizational question.    How many CUs can delegates effectively oversee?  1-5 6-10 11-15 16-25 26+     0 voters

content.content: I think it really depends on the subject matter of the CUs.
I think it all depends on workloads, personalities and other things like time.

CodeKnight:  What is the upper limit on how many CUs delegates can effectively manage?   I would actually be tempted to push back on the premise of the question: is it really true that delegates ‘manage’ CUs, at all? In my mental model of Maker, that’s the job of CU Facilitators. Delegates have enough on their plate needing to be across each function of Maker, for the purpose of casting regular votes on everything from RWA to stability fee changes. I don’t think it’s practical or desirable for delegates to also serve as day-to-day middle management for CUs.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: This would be great topic for discussion. Are delegates “the officers” or “the directors” or some combination of those. Personally I think we (delegates) should evaluate what is being delivered and presented, but not actively manage. I am in favor of delegate taking another responsibility based on their expertise, but it should be a separate role for them.

content.content: You are right. Oversee is a better word. I changed the title to reflect that. Although if you have KPIs, the difference isn’t that big. Personally, I talk to my manager once or twice a month and generally get a free hand as long as my metrics are good, which isn’t too different from Maker. People have different experiences though so the word can give the wrong connotation.

content.content: but then who holds the CUs accountable and how are activities coordinated across CUs?  Many key action require multiple CU involvement

I agree - I see the role of delegates as holding CUs accountable, ideally to agreed-upon KPIs and strategic objectives (great to see recently that good progress is being made on this front). I don’t think that this function necessitates ‘management’ per se (arguably the latter undermines the former) and agree with @CodeKnight’s change of terminology to ‘oversee’. That better reflects the dynamic, at least in my view. In terms of coordinating activity across CUs, that is a little different to the accountability question and I guess my answer would depend on the details and nature of the collaboration. CUs may well (and do) collaborate between themselves all the time on low-level issues, but you’re right that delegates likely have a role in directing larger-scale activities and strategic functions that include multiple CUs.

content.content: That is a good point. If one CU is dragging their feet on something, there isn’t a clear mediator to go to besides delegates. KPIs are likely to expose coordination pain points too, as people will inevitably attribute some of their poor KPIs to inaction from another CU.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: KPIs are important and valuable metrics but need to set carefully. E.g. if a CU had a mandate to grow vault balances by 10% but the market conditions change they would be way off their KPI. I am in favor of a 6-12 month forecast (KPI) that incorporates initiatives and macroeconomic factors which CUs track against and are able to provide commentary for variances.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Delegates are not tasked with overseeing Core Units. The responsibilities are to vote and communicate reasons for voting.

To be honest, there are several CUs that many delegates don’t know details or don’t even know they exist especially for newer delegates. But I don’t think it’s a matter of how many delegates can oversee because there are some CUs that are very difficult to oversee fully because either the update is seldom or it’s just very difficult to understand fully. So it’s not a matter of number of CUs in my opinion.

content.content: Doo_StableLab:  or don’t even know they exist especially for newer delegates   I would argue this is only acceptable because of how many CUs there are. Imagine we had 4 CUs and a delegate said “I don’t know why one of them exists” or “I haven’t spoken to that CU’s facilitator in 8 months”. These things happen because it’s easy for people to slip through the cracks when numbers get large.
